__data__.text: French governments have been addressing pension reforms to manage budget shortfalls, as France has a low retirement age and spends a high percentage of its GDP on pensions. The country's pay-as-you-go pension system, which is state-backed, has maintained low poverty rates among pensioners. However, increased life expectancy and a rising number of pensioners have resulted in a decreasing ratio of workers to retirees, from 2.1 in 2000 to a projected 1.2 in 2070. This shift, along with the high cost of pensions, has contributed to France's rising national debt, which reached 112% of GDP in 2023. To ensure the pension system's financial sustainability, President Macron proposed raising the retirement age to 64 or 65, increasing the number of years required for a full pension, and eliminating special rules for certain sectors.

In an effort to ensure the financial sustainability of France's pension system, which is a pay-as-you-go model funded by workers' contributions, President Macron has proposed pension reforms including raising the retirement age to 64 or 65 and increasing the number of years required for a full pension. These reforms were initially considered during Macron's 2017 election campaign and were delayed due to protests and the COVID-19 pandemic. The proposed changes also include eliminating special rules for certain sectors and gradually increasing the retirement age to 65 by 2031. These reforms are intended to address budget shortfalls caused by an increasing number of pensioners and a decreasing ratio of workers to retirees, which has contributed to France's rising national debt. The government estimates that the reforms will balance the deficit by 2030 and result in a surplus that can be used to fund early retirement for those in physically demanding jobs.

In his pursuit of pension reform to ensure the financial stability of France's pay-as-you-go pension system, President Macron proposed increasing the retirement age and the number of years required for a full pension. These changes, initially considered during his 2017 campaign, were postponed due to protests and the COVID-19 pandemic. Macron plans to implement the reforms by autumn 2023, with the possibility of flexibility regarding the retirement age increase to 65. The government aims to balance the pension system deficit by 2030 and explore alternative solutions.

The proposed changes include raising the contribution period for the full state pension from 42 to 43 years, meaning some individuals may work until 67. Macron's government has been negotiating with political figures to secure a majority in the lower house, while union leaders have warned that using Article 49.3 could worsen public opposition and escalate strikes. On 16 March, Macron decided to employ special powers instead of risking a vote, which he seemed likely to lose.

On March 16, Macron decided to use special powers (Article 49.3) to implement pension reforms, avoiding a likely defeat in the National Assembly vote. This sudden move reflects his precarious parliamentary position due to the majority loss in the 2022 legislative election. The reforms, including raising the retirement age and contribution period, are unpopular and have sparked strikes across various sectors. Trade unions argue that the changes will disproportionately affect low-income workers, forcing them to work longer. Polls show that a majority of people, including Macron's supporters, oppose the use of Article 49.3. The decision is perceived as a sign of weakness and brutality, causing Macron's approval ratings to drop significantly.

Macron's approval ratings have dropped significantly, reaching levels similar to the Yellow Jackets protests, due to the unpopular pension reforms. These reforms, which include raising the retirement age and contribution period, have been criticized for disproportionately affecting women, low-income workers, and those in manual jobs. Women, who typically retire later and with lower pensions, are expected to work an additional seven months under the new reforms. Blue-collar workers, who often start working at a younger age, may face age discrimination and be forced to retire later. The reforms have been perceived as favoring businesses and high-earners, with unions disputing the need for urgency and viewing the increase in the retirement age as unacceptable. The government's concession to allow early retirement for some in physically or mentally demanding jobs has not sufficiently addressed the opposition's concerns.

The pension reforms, which include increasing the retirement age and contribution period, have been met with criticism for disproportionately impacting women, low-income workers, and those in physically demanding jobs. Opponents argue that the government has exaggerated the threat of deficits and refuse alternatives such as raising worker payroll taxes or increasing taxes on the wealthy. The unpopularity of the reforms is also attributed to Macron's pre-existing negative image and the timing of the reform during a cost-of-living crisis. The protests have resulted in instances of violence and property damage, including the burning of union property and the presence of black bloc groups. The official body overseeing France's pension system has stated that there is no immediate threat of bankruptcy, challenging the government's argument for the urgency of the reforms.

The pension reform protests have involved black bloc groups engaging in violent methods such as looting and vandalism, with one instance resulting in the theft of €25,000 worth of gold in Rennes. On January 19, over 1.12 million people protested across France, with 80,000 in Paris, against the government's pension reform plan to raise the retirement age from 62 to 64 and increase annual pension contributions. Despite the large-scale demonstrations, Emmanuel Macron insisted on moving forward with the reforms. In response, French unions called for more strikes and protests on January 31. The protests have caused some disruptions in transportation, including flight cancellations and delays. The unions claim that 2 million people participated in the protests, while the government reported 1.12 million. The violence and property damage resemble previous incidents in the area, and the unpopularity of the reforms is attributed to Macron's negative image and the ongoing cost-of-living crisis.

Following the initial protests against the pension reform plan, which included transportation disruptions and violent incidents, further demonstrations took place on January 21 and 31, and February 7, 11, and 16. These demonstrations, organized by various groups, targeted public transport, schools, electricity production, and public television broadcasters, resulting in the cancellation of flights, delays, and strikes. The CGT union reported significantly higher numbers of participants than the Ministry of Internal Affairs. On February 16, the unions reported 1.3 million protesters nationwide, while the interior ministry estimated 440,000. The Intersyndicale called for recurring strikes starting on March 7. The new law would require 43 annual pension contributions instead of 41.

After the initial protests against the pension reform plan, the Intersyndicale called for recurring strikes starting from March 7. The strikes and protests continued in early March, affecting trains and resulting in flight cancellations. Union members blocked fuel deliveries to impact the French economy. On February 16, there were fresh rallies and strikes with 1.3 million people participating, according to unions, and 440,000 according to the interior ministry. On March 11, the seventh day of protests, about 368,000 people protested, and the Senate passed an initial vote on the reforms. On March 14, unions called for a final day of strikes and protests before the National Assembly vote, with an expected 200 protests across the country, and conflicting numbers of participants reported.

On March 15, eight unions coordinated the 15th nationwide protest day, referred to as "Greve 15 mars," against the pension reform plan. The turnout was disputed, with the Interior Ministry reporting 480,000 protesters and the CGT union claiming 1.78 million. Police expected 650,000-850,000 protesters, a decrease from the previous week. A diverse group of workers, including train drivers, teachers, and oil refinery workers, participated in the protests. Strikes impacted public transport, with 40% of high-speed trains and half the regional trains cancelled, and 20% of flights at Paris-Orly airport delayed or cancelled. Violence was reported in Rennes, Nantes, and Lyon, with security forces responding with charges and tear gas. Authorities urged Paris City Hall to address the ongoing garbage collectors' strike, which had reached its tenth day, due to health concerns. The mayor expressed support for the strike, leading to a government spokesman threatening intervention if the issue was not resolved.

Following the Paris mayor's support for the ongoing strike against pension reforms, the government threatened to intervene if the issue wasn't resolved. Amidst this tension, Prime Minister Borne invoked Article 49:3 of the constitution to enact the pension reforms without a parliamentary vote, causing protests and jeers from opposition MPs. Both the left and right of the political spectrum denounced the move, with some calling for no-confidence motions and criticizing the government for undermining the law's democratic legitimacy. The government had initially attempted to hold a parliamentary vote but changed tactics when it became clear they would not have enough support from their usual allies, The Republicans.

After realizing they didn't have enough support from their allies, The Republicans, to win a parliamentary vote on pension reforms, the government decided to enforce the reforms using Article 49:3. This move was criticized by both the left and right, with some calling for no-confidence motions and questioning the democratic legitimacy of the law. Following the announcement, protests erupted in the Place de la Concorde, with thousands gathering, some after being turned away from a separate protest. Jean-Luc Mélenchon, the leader of La France Insoumise, spoke to the crowd, denouncing the reform's legitimacy. As night fell, clashes with police occurred, resulting in injuries, arrests, and property damage. The protests were sparked by the government's decision to bypass a parliamentary vote on the pension reforms.

After the government enforced pension reforms using Article 49:3, protests broke out in several cities, including Place de la Concorde, where protesters clashed with police, resulting in injuries, arrests, and property damage. Radical groups were partially blamed for vandalism and looting in Marseille. The CGT announced further strikes and demonstrations for 23 March, denouncing the move as contempt towards the people and a violation of democracy. Riot police intervened at Place de la Concorde on 17 March, using tear gas to clear the square after protesters climbed scaffolding and threw objects at police. Over 300 people were arrested nationwide, and Macron made no public comments but warned about playing with the country's future in a closed-door meeting. Protesters chanted for Macron's resignation and referenced the French Revolution.

Following the government's implementation of pension reforms, widespread protests took place across France, including Place de la Concorde where protesters clashed with police, leading to arrests, injuries, and property damage. Radical groups were implicated in vandalism and looting in Marseille. Protesters demanded Macron's resignation, with some referencing the French Revolution. The CGT announced further strikes and demonstrations, while the 'black bloc' joined the protests. Disruptions occurred in Paris's Boulevard Périphérique and at refineries, with the Normandy refinery facing a potential shutdown. Smaller protests took place in various cities, and students protested near Sorbonne University. Strikes were also reported in Lille's Institute of Political studies.

After the government's pension reforms, the CGT union decided to escalate their strike at the TotalEnergies de Normandie refinery, potentially halting production by the weekend, which could lead to fuel shortages. Protests and strikes continued across France, involving CGT unionists, SNCF workers, and students. Unions from SNCF called for another continuous strike. Two no-confidence motions were tabled in the National Assembly, one led by the centrist group Liot and co-signed by NUPES with 91 MPs, and another by National Rally with 81 cross-party MPs. Interior Minister warned against chaos in street demonstrations, while Aurore Bergé, head of Renaissance in parliament, requested protection for MPs fearing violence. 18 March.

On 18 March, Aurore Bergé, the head of Renaissance in parliament, requested Interior Minister Darmanin to ensure the protection of MPs who feared violence from protesters. Darmanin responded that police would be vigilant against any violence towards lawmakers. Meanwhile, protests in Paris were banned on the Place de la Concorde and the Champs-Élysées due to potential public order disturbances, but demonstrators still gathered at Place d'Italie, chanting for Macron's resignation, setting trash cans alight, and clashing with riot police. Similar protests occurred in major cities, resulting in 169 arrests nationwide. The political office of the leader of the Republicans in Nice was ransacked, with threats of riots if the party didn't support any no-confidence motions. Firefighter sirens wailed as protesters marched towards Europe's biggest waste incineration plant in Paris.

Protests led to violence, arrests, and disruptions nationwide. In Nice, the office of the Republicans' leader was ransacked, and threats were made if the party didn't support no-confidence motions. Demonstrations in various cities, including Nantes, Marseille, Montpellier, Besançon, and Lyon, involved clashes with police, property damage, and occupations. Union actions include strikes at refineries, waste incinerators, and railways, with potential shutdowns and fuel shortages. The government may intervene to require workers to return to their jobs. Air traffic disruptions are expected at Orly Airport and Marseille for Monday, 20 March. Protests and associated unrest continue to escalate in multiple locations.

The government is considering forcing striking workers to return to their jobs to prevent fuel shortages, as protests and associated disruptions continue nationwide. This includes strikes at refineries, waste incinerators, and railways, leading to potential shutdowns, fuel shortages, and air traffic disruptions at Orly Airport and Marseille. Hundreds of protesters have gathered in various cities, with clashes and property damage reported. In response to vandalism of MPs' offices, President Macron has pledged support for legislators and measures to protect them. Macron and Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire have expressed hope that the pension reform bill will complete its democratic process, while Éric Ciotti, leader of the Republicans, has stated that his party will not support no-confidence motions, making it unlikely for them to pass.

Éric Ciotti, head of the Republicans, announced his party won't support no-confidence motions, making it unlikely for them to pass since the Republicans have significant influence in the National Assembly. Jean-Luc Mélenchon of NUPES urged protesters to avoid violence and continue demonstrating against the pension reform. Jordan Bardella of National Rally tried to persuade more Republicans to join the no-confidence motions by promising not to oppose them in potential elections. Union leaders anticipated significant flight cancellations on March 20 due to strikes, and airlines like easyJet, Ryanair, and Eurostar warned passengers of disruptions. Protests led to road blockades, clashes with police, and traffic disruptions in Rennes, which were later lifted.

Éric Ciotti's Republicans refuse to support no-confidence motions, reducing the chances of their success. Jean-Luc Mélenchon and Jordan Bardella continue to rally support for protests against the pension reform. Union strikes have resulted in significant flight disruptions, road blockades, and traffic disruptions in Rennes, which were later lifted. Protests have also led to clashes with police, tear gas usage, and reduced speed limits due to damaged roads. Industrial action at oil refineries has started to affect fuel supplies, causing shortages in Marseille and southern regions. Garbage collection strikes are set to continue until at least 20 March. SNCF warns of disrupted train services, and teachers' unions may disrupt baccalauréat exams starting 20 March. TotalEnergie experiences a 39% worker strike rate, causing fuel shortages and local restrictions in the southeast and west of the country.

The text discusses the ongoing impact of protests and strikes in France, particularly in relation to fuel shortages and disrupted services. In the southeast and west of the country, local authorities have limited fuel sales due to shortages caused by strikes at oil refineries and blockades. Approximately 7% of the country's petrol stations are affected by shortages, with major cities like Marseille and Paris potentially experiencing significant disruptions. The website Penurie.mon-essence.fr reports that over 980 fuel stations are experiencing partial or complete shortages.

Additionally, the text describes spontaneous protests in Paris following no-confidence votes, with protesters chanting for President Macron to step down. The protests escalated into the evening, resulting in barricades, burning of objects, and a heavy police presence. The violence is attributed to groups quickly moving through the capital. The fuel shortages are believed to be primarily caused by panic buying and preemptive purchases by consumers.

Protests in France, particularly in Paris, escalated into the evening with barricades, burning of objects, and a heavy police presence. The violence was caused by quick-moving groups, resulting in over 230 arrests, mainly for setting fires. Unions and opposition parties are planning to intensify protests to pressure a reversal of the pension reforms. Fuel shortages, primarily due to panic buying, continue to affect 7% of the country's petrol stations. Cities like Marseille and Paris may experience significant disruptions. Small, scattered protests occurred in other cities, with some escalating into violence. Prime Minister Borne announced that the new law would be reviewed by the Constitutional Council for constitutionality checks.

Following the escalation of protests in France, Prime Minister Borne announced that the new pension reform law would be immediately reviewed by the Constitutional Council, with the hope that all concerns raised during debates can be examined. The Constitutional Council will consider any objections to the bill within a month. Meanwhile, Macron stated that he will not dissolve the National Assembly, reshuffle the government, or call for a referendum, but instead will address the nation in a TV interview to calm things down and prepare for future reforms. There is reported unease within Macron's political allies about continuing normal governance during ongoing protests and strikes. Macron's government acknowledged their weakened position but offered no specifics on how they would involve the public and unions in future legislation. In total, 287 people were arrested nationwide due to the protests.

The text discusses the ongoing protests and strikes in France, which have resulted in the weakening of the government's position. Gilles Le Gendre, a senior MP from Macron's party, acknowledged the government's weakened state and urged for a different approach to the pension reform bill. Meanwhile, Patrick Vignal of the same party called for the suspension of the bill due to its unpopularity and the anger it has caused.

The protests have led to significant disruptions, including the cancellation of 20% of flights, blockades of oil terminals and gas depots, and strikes at multiple refineries. The government has responded by requisitioning workers to keep the oil storage facility in Fos-sur-Mer operational. Clashes between protesters and police have been reported, and the government has warned of further disruptions in the coming days.

Analysts have suggested that Macron has two options: to ignore the crisis and hope it resolves itself or to pursue a cohabitation with the opposition in the assembly. However, the analysts believe that Macron is more likely to choose the first option, which they view as a risky bet.

The protests in France have led to the blockading of various sites, including an oil depot in southeastern France and an incineration plant in Ivry-sur-Seine, causing fuel shortages and disruptions in waste management. Police have evacuated some blockaded areas and have ordered rubbish collectors to return to work to maintain a minimum service. Protesters have clashed with police, and some have resorted to setting skips alight during protests. Meanwhile, Macron has defended the pension reform as a necessity, despite its unpopularity. The government has warned of further disruptions and has requisitioned workers to keep some facilities operational. Analysts suggest that Macron may choose to ignore the crisis and hope for a resolution, a move they view as risky.

The protests in France on March 22 resulted in skips being set on fire in Rennes and disruptions in train services in Nice and Toulouse. Union leaders criticized Macron's recent interview, with Philippe Martinez of the CGT calling it "outlandish" and Laurent Berger of the CFDT accusing Macron of lying. Marine Le Pen refused to help resolve the political crisis created by Macron, who she claims has shown disdain for workers. The oil refinery blockades have caused fuel shortages in 13% of petrol stations and nearly half the pumps in the Bouches-du-Rhône area. Despite police evacuating some blockaded areas and requisitioning workers, analysts view Macron's decision to ignore the crisis as risky. Macron has maintained his confidence in Prime Minister Borne and defended the pension reform as a necessity, despite its unpopularity.

On March 22, unions announced that a significant number of primary school teachers would strike, with up to half expected to participate in the ongoing protests. The eighth nationwide day of action on March 23 was marked by major disruptions in public transportation, with only two Paris metro lines operating normally and significant reductions in regional TER and TGV/Ouigo services. Unionists and strikers demonstrated at various locations, including Gare de Lyon train station and Charles de Gaulle Airport. Exam supervisors also went on strike, affecting over half a million baccalauréat students. Workers at an LNG terminal in Dunkirk reduced output to a minimum, and fuel shortages were reported in 14% of petrol stations, with 7% completely dry.

The strikes expanded to exam supervisors, impacting over half a million baccalauréat students. Workers at the Dunkirk LNG terminal reduced output, resulting in fuel shortages in 14% of petrol stations. The protest movement broadened, with the barricading of prominent institutions and closures of major tourist attractions. Large demonstrations occurred in multiple cities, with a significant police presence. There is widespread anger towards the government, as demonstrated by the posters and slogans during the protests. The number of protesters was substantial, with varying estimates from different sources.

The demonstrations in Paris saw posters demanding the retirement age reversion to 60 and depicting Macron as Louis XVI. A large number of protesters, including "black bloc" members, caused violent clashes with police who used tear gas and baton charges. The protests led to arrests, property damage, and the use of a controversial police unit. The main demonstration route became congested, causing protesters to spill onto side streets. Most protests were peaceful, but certain areas of Paris experienced violence. The protests resulted in fires, property damage, and the deployment of a controversial police unit.

The protests against pension reform in France extended to various cities, including Paris, Marseille, Nice, Toulon, Lyon, Normandy, Rouen, Rennes, Tours, and Lorient. In Paris, the "Motos Brav-M" police unit, known for alleged excessive force, was met with hostility. Thousands protested in several cities, leading to disrupted train services, blocked roads, and clashes with police involving tear gas and water cannons. Some instances of property damage and fires were reported, as well as attacks on police stations and government buildings in Lorient.

The anti-pension reform protests in France, which took place in numerous cities such as Paris, Lorient, Bordeaux, and Rouen, resulted in significant disruptions and clashes with police. In Lorient, a local prefecture office and a police station were targeted, with attempts to storm the building and set it on fire. The Interior Minister condemned these attacks and reported 123 police officers injured nationwide, with an independent journalist claiming 149 injuries in Paris alone. Instances of property damage, including a fire at the Palais Rohan in Bordeaux and a young woman losing her thumb in Rouen due to police action, were reported. Union head Berger urged for non-violence and respect for property and people. Over 80 people were arrested, and shortages of firefighters led to locals extinguishing fires in Paris.

The 28th of March saw a tenth day of protests against the pension reform, with an estimated 740,000 attendees according to the French government, and 2 million according to unions. Union leaders, including Berger and Martinez, spoke out in the afternoon, with Berger advocating for non-violence and respect for property and people. The protests resulted in significant disruptions, including shortages of firefighters and instances of property damage. Prime Minister Borne agreed to talks with eight leading union leaders the following week, but both sides remained firm on their positions regarding the pension reform. On the 14th of April, the Constitutional Council declared the pension bill to be compatible with the Constitution, and Macron signed it into law later that same day. Union leaders had previously met with Macron, and the government is now working to implement the changes by September 1st.

In summary, the anti-pension reform protests in France resulted in significant disruptions and clashes with police, with both sides remaining firm on their positions regarding the pension reform. The Constitutional Council declared the bill to be compatible with the Constitution, and Macron signed it into law. Union leaders had previously met with Macron, and the government is now working to implement the changes.

Before the pension bill was signed into law, Prime Minister Borne stated that the democratic process for the proposal was nearing its end, and there were "no winners or losers." Despite union leaders rejecting Macron's invitation for a meeting, he vowed to implement a government action plan within 100 days to address anger over the pension reform and other issues. Protests and clashes with police occurred as Macron toured France, with protesters jeering, banging pots and pans, and holding signs threatening to cancel the 2024 Summer Olympics if the pension reform was not withdrawn. Effigies of Macron and Interior Minister Darmanin were abused or burned across France on International Workers' Day.

After the pension bill became law, French President Macron faced protests and clashes with police during his tour of France, where he was met with jeers and pot-banging. Effigies of Macron and Interior Minister Darmanin were vandalized or burned across the country. The May Day protests saw 2.3 million people (per organizers) and 800,000 people (per French authorities) taking to the streets, resulting in 108 injured police officers, 19 seriously injured in Paris, and 291 arrests. Following the protests, unions announced further nationwide protests on June 6, marking the 14th wave against the pension reform. The government expressed its desire to focus on other issues and invited unions for talks to discuss their opposition to the reform and improve workers' conditions. France's Constitutional Council rejected a second referendum bid, leading to more protests, including some in Paris' financial district. On Victory Day, law enforcement banned gatherings in Paris and Lyon, but protests and pot-banging still occurred, resulting in tear gas being deployed by authorities.

After the pension bill became law, France experienced ongoing protests against the reform, with increasing concerns over violence. The protests led to clashes with police, disruptions in public transportation, and the banning of gatherings in certain areas. Protesters have been particularly critical of the government's use of force, drawing comparisons to the violent Yellow Vests protests in the past. Despite the ban on protests, hospital workers and others have continued to demonstrate, resulting in the deployment of a large number of law enforcement officers. The protests have had a significant impact, causing the cancellation of flights and the temporary occupation of the 2024 Summer Olympics headquarters in Paris. The French government has expressed its desire to focus on other issues and has invited unions for talks to discuss their opposition to the reform and improve workers' conditions. The Iranian Foreign Ministry has called on the French government to refrain from violence against protesters.

The protests in France against the pension bill have escalated in violence, reminiscent of the Yellow Vest movement, with increasing radicalization and clashes with police. The unions, although initially united, have expressed concerns about losing control of the protests to more extreme demonstrators. The government's use of force has been criticized, and there are fears of further violent anti-government protests. The unions have admitted that the growing anger and radicalization are inevitable and the government's fault. The heads of moderate unions have expressed concerns about the violence and the impression that only violence is effective. The objective of some protesters is reportedly the defeat of the president.

The leaders of moderate unions, Cyril Chabanier (CFTC) and Laurent Berger (CFDT), have voiced concerns about the escalating violence and radicalization during the protests against the pension bill, which they believe is due to the government's handling of the situation. Moderate unions condemn the violence but are worried that the growing anger, even within their ranks, may lead to increased radicalization. Meanwhile, some protesters aim to topple the president. The waste collectors' strike, which began on March 6, has resulted in uncollected trash piling up on Parisian streets, with an estimated 10,000 tonnes of waste as of March 17. Politicians, including those from the president's party, have received threatening emails and experienced vandalism at their offices. The recent protests have been intense but not large in scale, mainly involving dedicated left-wing activists.

The waste collectors' strike in Paris, which began on March 6, has led to the halting of bin lorries and waste incinerators in the Paris area. This has resulted in a significant buildup of uncollected trash, with an estimated 10,000 tonnes as of March 17. The Interior Minister has attempted to use emergency powers to force strikers back to work, but the Paris mayor and her deputy maintain that this would be unconstitutional. The strike has also affected other cities, and the priority is to clear food waste to prevent pests.

The ongoing waste collectors' strike in Paris, which began on March 6, has resulted in significant piled up of uncollected trash, with an estimated 10,000 tonnes by March 17. The strike has also affected other cities, with food waste being the priority for collection due to health concerns. The Interior Minister's attempt to use emergency powers to force strikers back to work has been contested as unconstitutional by the Paris mayor and her deputy. The strike was suspended on March 29 due to declining participation, partly because of the requisitions order by the Paris police.

The police have been accused of arbitrarily detaining and charging protesters, including those who were just passing by, with many cases being closed without charges or with only warnings. Some lawyers, including Coline Bouillon, plan to file a collective complaint against the police for "arbitrary detention" and "obstruction of the freedom to demonstrate." This tactic has been criticized by politicians, judges, and lawyers, who view it as a means to suppress the protest movement, similar to the government's approach during the gilet jaunes protests. The Syndicat de la Magistrature (SM) and Raphaël Kempf, a French lawyer specializing in judiciary repression methods, share this perspective.

The Syndicat de la Magistrature (SM) and a lawyer specializing in judiciary repression methods, Raphaël Kempf, have criticized the government's use of criminal law to discourage demonstrators, which they believe is a form of judicialization of policing that started 15 years ago. A 2010 law initially intended to combat gang violence and protect sporting venues has been expanded to cover protests and demonstrations. Critics have raised concerns about violent confrontations and indiscriminate arrests at rallies. The police have been accused of sexual assault during controls and using disproportionate force, including stun grenades, during demonstrations. Many officers have been injured during the protests. The police watchdog is investigating the allegations of sexual assault, and some lawyers plan to file a collective complaint against the police for arbitrary detention and obstruction of the freedom to demonstrate.

The Syndicat de la Magistrature and lawyer Raphaël Kempf criticize the French government's use of criminal law to discourage demonstrators, resulting in violent confrontations, indiscriminate arrests, and allegations of police misconduct, including sexual assault and disproportionate force. During a Paris demonstration, a British journalist reported police brutality and indiscriminate use of stun grenades, causing injuries to both officers and protesters. Macron's pension reform proposal has drawn comparisons to former President Sarkozy's 2010 reform, which led to significant political backlash. Invoking Article 49.3 may further erode support for the government and democratic institutions. Alternative solutions, such as replacing the Prime Minister, using a referendum, or exploring other options, have been suggested in response to the pension reform controversy.

After the pension reform controversy, there were suggestions that Macron might replace the Prime Minister or hold a referendum to let voters decide on the reforms. However, no-confidence votes failed, and the enactment of the law seemed inevitable. One remaining option was a shared-initiative referendum (RIP), which requires support from one-fifth of both the National Assembly and Senate, as well as signatures of a tenth of the electorate within nine months. NUPES claimed to have the necessary support since March 14, and starting the process could delay the pension reforms, affecting Macron's plans to introduce changes from September. Additionally, NUPES members planned to appeal to the Constitutional Council, and if the bill had passed by vote, several appeals would have been made.

Following the pension reform controversy, NUPES planned to appeal to the Constitutional Council, arguing that the reform is a legislative rider and unconstitutional, as it was inserted into the social security budget and lacks clear calculations. They also aimed to delay the enactment of the law by initiating a shared-initiative referendum. Meanwhile, the scheduled state visit of King Charles III and Queen Camilla to France was met with criticism due to ongoing protests and the perceived inappropriateness of attending a lavish dinner at Versailles Palace during a time of social unrest. Some politicians called for the trip to be cancelled or postponed, emphasizing the need to address domestic issues instead.

After the pension reform controversy, NUPES planned to challenge the reform's constitutionality and delay its enactment through a shared-initiative referendum. Amidst this, the scheduled state visit of King Charles III faced criticism due to ongoing protests and perceived inappropriateness. The visit was initially planned for 27 March, but due to union strikes on the 28th, it was postponed to the summer. Some politicians expressed disappointment, while others were pleased with the cancellation. The French Human Rights League criticized the authorities for excessive force and arbitrary arrests during protests. International reactions included Iran condemning France's handling of protests and urging respect for human rights.

Following the pension reform controversy, criticism of the French government's handling of protests has grown, with various human rights organizations and international entities denouncing the use of excessive force, arbitrary arrests, and violations of freedom of expression and the press. Rights groups, including the National Consultative Commission on Human Rights and Reporters Without Borders, have expressed concerns over preventative arrests, abusive police practices, and attacks on journalists during demonstrations. The UN Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Association and the Council of Europe have urged French authorities to respect the right to peaceful assembly and avoid disproportionate use of force. The White House and the Communist Party of Greece have also voiced support for the right to protest in France.
